Key Arguments: The submission argues that the claims about the harms of misinformation and disinformation are made without evidence or examples.
It questions the assumption that certain categories of content producers (e.g., professional news, educational institutions) are infallible and incapable of spreading misinformation.
The submission challenges the ability of ACMA to prove that misinformation causes harm and criticizes the lack of requirement for solid data to support ACMA's claims.
It argues that the bill is unnecessary and will cause more harm than good, potentially leading to unintended consequences.
The submission views the legislation as a restriction on free speech and an overreach by the government, suggesting it undermines Australians' ability to think for themselves.
Notable Quotes: You have made the above claims without giving any evidence for or examples of these claims.
This bill is not needed. It will cause more harm than good.
It is a restriction on free speech. The penalties are grossly excessive.
